Heating, ventilation and air-conditioning systems (HVAC), at demand side, are regarded as promising candidates to provide demand response to smart power grids by adjusting indoor temperature setpoint. However, the optimal control of indoor temperature setpoint with the constraint of indoor environment is a key issue. In this study, an XGBoost-based predictive control strategy is proposed for HVAC systems in providing day-ahead demand response. XGBoost (Extreme Gradient Boosting) models are developed to predict the variation of power use and indoor temperature. Several innovations are implemented to improve the performance of the control strategy, including dedicated generation of the initial population of genetic algorithm (GA) in rolling optimization, the use of a step-decreasing control horizon, and the separation of the sampling period and control action period. The strategy is validated on a TRNSYS-Python co-simulation test platform. Results show that the developed XGBoost models can achieve a high prediction performance of power use (CV-RMSE of 4.52%) and indoor temperature (CV-RMSE of 0.40%) in the coming 10 min with only using one-week historical data. The computation cost is reduced by 78% due to the dedicated generation of GA initial population while the control performance is not affected. Compared with the traditional operation, the proposed control strategy can reduce the total cost by as much as 27.30% and 33.6% while the weighted indoor temperature only increases by 0.14 K and 0.62 K, respectively. In test cases, the highest Predicted Mean Vote (PMV) is 0.72 and the corresponding Predicted Percentage of Dissatisfied (PPD) is 15.9%. First, for the demand side, the load varies significantly through the year/day, which results in a high rate of peak and average power demand. Second, for the supply side, the increasing penetrations of intermittent renewable power generations (e.g., wind and solar power) decrease the reliability of power generation. To meet the peak power demand, many power plants are built every year, which leads to higher energy costs and dramatically decrease in the annual working hours of generators [1]. Demand response (DR) is considered a promising solution which is an approach to stimulate end users to change their power use profile by adjusting their regular consumption patterns with monetary incentives. In this way, the peak power demand can be decreased or shifted. In recent years, many policies have been passed to encourage the resources at demand side to provide demand response [2]. In China, eight provinces have issued their policies in the first half year of 2022. Guangdong, one of these eight provinces, issued “Detailed implementing rules for market-oriented demand response of Guangdong Province” on April 16, 2022 [3]. According to this rule, demand resources can submit the reward price they are willing to receive for providing demand response, and the final reward price is determined through market bidding. According to the bidding result, the current reward price is around 3 RMB/kW·h (i.e., 0.42 U S. dollar/kW·h). Among various types of demand resources, heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems in buildings are one of the most promising candidates to provide demand response. There are two reasons. First, it accounts for a large proportion of power consumption. The building sector consumes about 40% of global energy used [4], and HVAC systems account for a large proportion (e.g., around 50% in the U.S. [5]) of building energy consumption. Second, it can easily change the power use profile by adjusting the indoor temperature setpoint. Because of the heat storage in thermal mass, the real indoor temperature variation can be alleviated. To generate an optimal sequence of indoor temperature setpoints, many studies are conducted by using the model predictive control (MPC) technology. MPC is an advanced method of process control that can use a predictive model of the control object (e.g., building and/or HVAC system) to predict its future behavior in the prediction horizon. According to the control target (e.g., comfort satisfaction and minimization of cost) and optimization algorithm, the controller can find the most desirable behavior (e.g., power use profile) and its corresponding control action sequence (e.g., indoor temperature setpoint sequence). The controller only implements the first control action of the control action sequence. In the next time step, the optimization is conducted again, which generates a new control action sequence. This feature is called rolling optimization which can take full use of the updated information to improve the control performance [6]. Several review papers have been published that systematically introduce the framework and evolution of MPC for buildings, including the study of Afram and Janabi-Sharifi [7] in 2014, the study of Serale et al. [8] in 2018, and the study of Drgona et al. [6] in 2020. Readers are encouraged to read these classical reviews for an overview of MPC in buildings. Some representative studies that use MPC for demand response are introduced in the following paragraph. In the study of Ma et al. [9], an economic model predictive control technique in reducing energy and demand costs for building HVAC systems was proposed. In this study, linear models were built to predict the power use of the HVAC system and the indoor temperature. The optimization was formulated and converted into a linear programming problem which was efficiently solved. Later in their another study [10], the control strategy was further experimentally validated in a commercial office building in the U.S. In the study of Hu and Xiao [11], the resistance-capacitance (RC) room thermal model and a steady-state model of air conditioning system were developed. The result shows that compared with the baseline case, the proposed model-based optimal control method could reduce the whole electricity costs and the peak power demands during demand response period while meeting thermal comfort constraints. In the study of Li et al. [12], an MPC controller was developed and then validated by simulation and experiment. A linear state-space model was developed for indoor temperature dynamics, while the HVAC system was modeled by a quasi-steady-state model. The experimental result shows that the MPC controller reduced the total electrical energy consumption by more than 20% on average while improving thermal comfort in terms of indoor temperature. In the study of Tang et al. [13], Support Vector Regression (SVR) models were trained to predict the power use of the HVAC system and the indoor temperature. The SVR-based MPC was then compared with the RC-based MPC. The genetic algorithm (GA) was used to solve the optimization problem. It is found that the SVR-based MPC could alleviate the time/labor cost of model development without sacrificing the control performance. In the study of Hilliard et al. [14], a random forest regression model was used to predict power use and indoor temperature in the next time step, and genetic algorithm was used to solve the nonlinear optimization problem. A four-month experimental test period shows a 29% HVAC electric energy reduction and a 63% thermal energy reduction compared to previous years for the same time period. Although there are many existing studies on the model predictive control of building HVAC systems, there are serval research gaps that need to be studied. (1) Under the circumstance of online optimal control, many studies use linear models to describe the dynamic behavior of building and HVAC systems because they are easy to implement and the optimization problem can be easily converted into a linear programming problem that can be efficiently solved. However, the linear model has its limitation on prediction accuracy because these systems are nonlinear, especially the HVAC systems [6]. Therefore, it is necessary to explore the use of emerging machined learning technologies (most nonlinear) for high-accuracy prediction. In this study, XGBoost models are used for the prediction of HVAC power use and indoor temperature when the indoor temperature setpoint is changed. Here, XGBoost model is an ensemble model based on boosting theory, which has outstanding performance in machine learning competitions (e.g., Kaggle). To the best of the authors' knowledge, this is the first study to use XGBoost technology in MPC for the demand response control of building HVAC systems. (2) When a non-linear model is adopted for prediction, it forms a nonlinear optimization programming problem which is normally solved by intelligent algorithms [13,14], e.g., genetic algorithm (GA). However, its computational efficiency is relatively low, which could be an obstacle for real applications. In this study, the characteristic of GA and the rolling optimization are properly combined to decrease the computation cost. In the conventional rolling optimization process, the controller only implements the first control action and the rest are discarded. In this study, although only the first control action is implemented, the reset control action sequence is not discarded. Instead, it is converted as part of individuals in the initial population for genetic algorithm in the next time step. (3) In previous studies, the sampling period is normally equal to the control action period. However, this could cause some problems which are explained as follows. Normally, the sampling period should be defined by the Nyquist criterion, but in practice, a smaller sampling time is advised [6] because it can better capture the dynamic behavior of the control object. According to statistics, the sampling period in 64 papers is lower than 30 min in a total of 112 papers [8]. However, a small control action period can cause the fluctuation of control action, which is found in our trial study and published studies [9,10]. This fluctuation cannot bring benefit to the control target, instead, it can damage the stable operation of the system in practice. Therefore, in this study, the control action period (1 h) is separated from the sampling period (10 min). In addition, a step-decreasing control horizon (the same as the prediction horizon in this study) is used. This means that the control horizon decreases each step which only covers the period from the current time to the closing time of the building in a day. The step-decreasing control horizon can also decrease the number of optimal variables to increase the computational speed. (4) In previous studies, most studies focus on the variation of indoor temperature while the humidity variation is neglected. In this study, the humidity, Predicted Mean Vote (PMV), and Predicted Percentage of Dissatisfied (PPD) are also studied. To obtain a reliable conclusion, a high-fidelity building HVAC environment is built considering detailed humidity-related information including moisture gain, infiltration rate, fresh air rate, and fresh air control method. Besides the innovations corresponding to the research gap mentioned above, the contribution of this study also lies in the practical reference value of the financial reward and cost reduction by adopting the proposed control strategy to provide demand response. This information is especially demanding to the commercial building manager in Guangdong Province regulated by the newly issued policy. The paper is organized as follows. The framework of the study is elaborated in Section 2. The principle and development process of the XGBoost model is introduced in Section 3. The MPC controller implementation is elaborated in Section 4. In Section 5, the test platform is introduced. In Section 6, the results of the control strategy performance are presented and discussed. The conclusions are made in Section 7. 2 Framework of the study In this section, the framework of the study is introduced, as shown in Fig. 1 . The research procedure is described as follows. (1) A reference commercial building in Shenzhen is investigated and a survey is conducted with the building manager. (2) Based on this building, a virtual building HVAC system is built in TRNSYS 18 (64-bit) [15], detailed introduced in Section 5. (3) An indoor temperature setpoint sequence is designed. Based on this sequence, the virtual building HVAC system is used to generate corresponding output signals (i.e., the indoor temperature and the HVAC system power use); (4) According to the information mentioned in the last step and other disturbances (i.e., weather condition, time information), two XGBoost models are trained in Python 3.6 (64-bit) for predicting indoor temperature and the HVAC system power use, respectively. (5) MPC controller using GA algorithm is also developed in Python to generate indoor temperature setpoints for the building HVAC system; (6) The developed MPC and the building HVAC system are combined as a TRNSYS-Python co-simulation test platform. (7) The variation of indoor temperature, indoor humidity, and power use under control is obtained for analysis. It should be noted that the proposed control strategy is a hierarchical control. In an upper layer, the proposed MPC is used to optimize the indoor temperature setpoint. In a lower layer, conventional PID control is used for the air conditioning system to track the optimized indoor temperature setpoint. 3 Development of XGBoost models for MPC In this section, the principle and development process of the XGBoost model is presented. 3.1 Model principle XGBoost belongs to boosting algorithm (belonging to supervised learning) which is different from bagging algorithm. In the bagging algorithm, for example, the random forest, the targets of each learner (i.e., Decision Tree) are the same, and the average value of these learners is considered as the result. By comparison, in XGBoost, a new learner (i.e., Decision Tree) is generated to fit the residual of the previous trees through continuous iteration [16]. The sum of these learners is considered as the result. (1) y ˆ i ( m ) = ∑ k = 1 m f k ( x i ) = y ˆ i ( m − 1 ) + f m ( x i ) where, y ˆ i ( m ) is the final tree model; y ˆ i ( m − 1 ) is the previously generated tree model; f m ( x i ) is the newly generated tree model, and m is the total number of base tree models. According to the principle in XGBoost, it can be found that a new tree is generated dedicated to decreasing the prediction error. Therefore, it normally has a high prediction performance. The problem of finding the optimal algorithm is changed into finding a new learner that can reduce the loss function, as shown in Eq. (2). (2) O b j ( m ) = ∑ i = 1 m L ( y i , y ˆ i ( m ) ) + ∑ i = 1 m Ω ( f i ) where, y i is the actual value; y ˆ i ( m ) is the predicted value; L ( y i , y ˆ i ( m ) ) is the loss function and Ω ( f i ) is the regularization term whose function is to prevent overfitting and improve model prediction accuracy, the XGBoost algorithm can accept both continues variables and discrete variables as inputs but the output variable has to be discrete, including binary variables [17]. XGBoost has some prominent features which make it different from other gradient boosting algorithms including clever penalization of trees, a proportional shrinking of leaf nodes, built-in cross-validation, allows for regularization to prevent overfitting, and allows for parallel and distributed computing to give a quicker modeling process. 3.2 Model development details As mentioned in Section 2, the outputs of the prediction mode are indoor temperature and power use of the HVAC system. To determine the inputs, a theoretical analysis is conducted as follows. First, the weather condition (outdoor temperature T o u t , and humidity H o u t ) and indoor temperature setpoint T i n , s e t can significantly influence the indoor temperature T i n and cooling load (related to power use P). Second, the calendar information, hour of the day (t), could reflect the space usage schedule, e.g., person, lighting, and equipment [18]. Third, because of the thermal inertia, historical information should also be considered. The step change of the indoor temperature setpoint is conducted and the time constant obtained is about 50 min. In this study, the sampling period is set as 10 min. Therefore, the historical data in the past 5 steps are considered, including 6 variables T o u t , H o u t , T i n , s e t , t, T i n , P. In summary, there are 34 inputs in total, including 4 variables ( T o u t , H o u t , T i n , s e t , t) in the next step and historical 30 (i.e., 6 × 5 ) variables. To obtain the data for the development of the prediction model, dedicated working condition is designed and performed on the virtual building HVAC system. A random sequence is generated as the indoor temperature setpoint, the lower and upper bounds of the random sequence are 23.5 °C and 26.5 °C respectively, which are 0.5 °C lower/higher than the thermal comfort region in this study [24 °C, 26 °C]. The data collection period is 7 days. Only the dataset within working hours is retained (from 7 a.m. to 9 p.m.) while the other dataset is discarded. It should be announced that in the trial stage of this study, the operation data of 30 days are collected, while it is found that the data of 7 days is sufficient. There are more than 30 different hyperparameters in the XGBoost. However, they have different levels of importance. The hyperparameters tuning process is described as follows. First, the tree-specific parameters are tuned by the grid search method, including the max depth of a tree and the subsample ratio (to grow a tree). Second, the alpha (L1 regularization parameter), and lambda (L2 regularization parameter) are tuned to help reduce model complexity and enhance performance. At last, the learning rate is decreased and the number of trees is increased until no performance improvement is observed. To evaluate the performance of the prediction model, four performance indices are used, including two scale-dependent metrics, mean absolute error (MAE), root means square error (RMSE), and two scale-independent metrics, R 2 and the coefficient of variation of the root mean squared error (CV-RMSE). Scale-dependent metrics can give readers a straightforward impression of the prediction error of a certain case while scale-independent metrics are convenient for comparison with other similar studies [5]. (7) min J = C e + C D R + C c f where J is the total cost which is a combination of electricity cost ( C e ), financial reward for providing demand response ( C D R negative) and comfort cost ( C c f ) which are defined by Eqs. 8–10 respectively. (8) C e = ∑ t = 1 n E c ( t ) ∙ Pr e ( t ) where E c is the energy consumption of the HVAC system; Pr e is the electricity price for energy consumption. In Shenzhen, electricity price is divided into four levels. This information is illustrated in the result and discussion part in Section 6 for the convenience of analysis with other figures. (9) C D R = ∑ t = 1 n E c d ( t ) ∙ Pr D R ( t ) where E c d is the energy consumption decrease compared with the case under normal operation without providing demand response. Pr D R is the reward price for providing demand response. It is set as 3 RMB/kW·h during demand response period which is broadcast days ahead. In this study, the demand response period is from 10:00 to 12:00 and from 14:00 to 16:00. For the simulation study in this paper, the power use baseline curve under normal operation without providing demand response can be easily obtained. However, in a real application, when the system is controlled for demand response, there is no chance to know its real power use baseline curve. There are two ways to address this problem. First, the power use baseline curve can be predicted according to historical power use data and weather conditions, which has been studied in many papers. Second, according to the policy in Guangdong Province, China [3], for simplicity, the power use baseline curve can be regarded as the average of the power use curve in the previous 5 days (working days) or 3 days (non-working days). (10) C c f = α ∙ T r i s e (11) T r i s e = ∑ t = 1 n ( T i n ( t ) − T i n , o r i g ) ∙ S p ( t ) ∑ t = 1 n S p ( t ) where α is the punishment parameter for indoor temperature sacrifice. T r i s e is the weighted temperature increase considering the schedule of person. T i n is the indoor temperature, T i n , o r i g is the indoor temperature under normal operation without providing demand response. In this study, it is 25 °C. S p is the schedule of person. 4.2 Rolling optimization The XGBoost model is a nonlinear model which forms a nonlinear optimization problem. In this study, the genetic algorithm (GA) is used in rolling optimization because of its prominent performance in solving nonlinear optimization problems. GA is an evolutionary algorithm inspired by the process of natural selection. It makes a population of individuals evolve to an optimal solution through successive modifications. At each modification, the genetic algorithm selects individuals from the current population to be parents and uses them to produce the children for the next generation by mutation, crossover, and selection [19]. Over successive generations, the population “evolves” toward an optimal solution. However, the computational efficiency is low when a large number of individuals and generations are set to find the globally optimal solution, which could be an obstacle for real applications. In this study, the characteristic of GA and the rolling optimization are properly combined to decrease the computation cost. In the process of rolling optimization, although only the first control action is implemented, the reset sequence is not discarded (as shown in Fig. 2 ). Instead, it is converted as part of individuals in the initial population for GA in the next time step. The other individuals are randomly generated. The reason is elaborated as follows. The fundamental of rolling optimization is that the system can update the latest information at each step and based on this updated information, the controller can predict more precisely and improve the control performance. However, in practice, the updated information doesn't change too much and the optimal control action doesn't change significantly. Therefore, the discarded sequence in the last step is a very proper starting point for the individuals in GA to find the optimal solution in the next step. Compared with the conventional implementation in which the initial population of GA is randomly generated, the dedicated generation of the initial population can significantly decrease the population size and iteration required to find the optimal solution. There are two points that need to be noticed. First, at the first step in a day, there is no previous control action sequence. Under such circumstances, the control action sequence in the previous day can be used. Second, the proportion of these artificial individuals set in the optimization problem in the next step (i.e., γ in Fig. 2) should not be too large. In this way, these individuals can crossover with other randomly generated individuals to avoid the local convergency issue. In this study, this proportion is set as 10%. In this study, the GA is implemented using Python with the scikit-opt package [20]. However, this package doesn't provide any function to automatically design the initial generation in GA. Therefore, the programming work was conducted, which can translate the indoor temperature setpoints in decimal to the corresponding binary code and then to the Gray code for the use of GA. 4.3 Periods/horizons in the controller Periods and horizons in the controller are shown in Fig. 3 . As mentioned in Section 3.2, the sampling period is set as 10 min. This means the XGBoost model is used to predict the power use of the HVAC system and the indoor temperature in the coming 10 min. Then the model iteratively predicts the following part. A relatively small sampling period is selected to better capture the dynamic behavior of the building HVAC system. However, the control action could fluctuate significantly if it is set too short (e.g., 10 min), which is found in our trial study and existing published studies [9,10]. Because the energy price is changed once 1 h, the optimization result of the indoor temperature setpoint in an hour could be like this sequence [24,26,24,26,24,26 °C]. Because of the thermal inertia and PID control delay, the real indoor temperature is actually near 25 °C. The total power consumption in this hour is also close to the case when the indoor temperature is set constant at 25 °C. In summary, this fluctuation cannot bring benefit to the optimal target, instead, it could damage the stable operation of the system in practice. Therefore, in this study, the control action period (for changing the indoor temperature setpoint) is separated from the sampling period and set as 1 h. This implementation can also decrease the optimal variables and accelerate the computation process. This is an outstanding advantage compared with another alternative to solve the fluctuation of control action in which a punishment on control action fluctuation can be added to the cost function. In this study, a step-decreasing control horizon (same as the prediction horizon in this study) is employed. This means that the control horizon decreases each step which only covers the period from the current time to the closing time of the building in a day (i.e., 9 p.m.). The step-decreasing control horizon can also decrease the optimal variables to increase the computational speed. 5 Test platform 5.1 Virtual building HVAC system The virtual building HVAC system is set up based on a real commercial building in Shenzhen. To build a high-fidelity building HVAC simulation environment. Two efforts have been made. First, to verify the state working condition of the system, the building HVAC system is operated with a constant indoor temperature of 25 °C, and the daily electricity cost of the HVAC system is calculated (about 7145 RMB in July). Second, to verify the dynamic behavior of the system, a step change of indoor temperature setpoint is implemented and the time constant of the system is tested (about 50 min). It is found that the daily electricity cost and time constant obtained from the virtual building HVAC system is close to the real case. 5.1.1 Building model This reference commercial building has 5 floors with a total floor area of approximately 27,000 m2 served by a typical VAV air-conditioning system. In this study, the model Type 56 in TRNSYS is used which is a detailed physical building model. The parameter of the envelope, including external walls (1.194 W/m2·k), and windows (2.480 W/m2·k), are set according to the survey and local design standards [21]. The parameters of the material in each layer of the wall are obtained with reference to Appendix B in “Code for thermal design of civil building” [22]. Internal mass can significantly impact the thermal dynamic of buildings [23,24]. According to a review [25], 50 kg/m2 wood/plastic material (density: 800 kg/m3, thermal conductivity: 0.2 w/m·k, specific heat capacity: 1400 J/kg·k, thickness: 0.018 m) is set in the building model. In addition, according to the survey, 0.44 m2 internal wall (density: 1800 kg/m3, thermal conductivity: 0.89w/m·k, specific heat capacity: 1000 J/kg·k, thickness: 0.28 m) are set per square meter of the floor. According to the local design standard [21], the lighting power and equipment power are 10 W/m2 and 13 W/m2 respectively. The internal gain from lighting and equipment can be split into convective and radiative components (lighting heat gains: 50% convective and 50% radiative; equipment heat gains: 67% convective and 33% radiative) [26]. The design density of occupants is 8 m2 per person. The moisture gain is set at 80 g/h per person. The sensible heat gain is 75 W per person (42% convective and 58% radiative) according to Table 1 in Chapter 18 of the ASHRAE Handbook [27]. The infiltration rate is set at 0.5 [28]. The fresh air is set at 30 m3/h per person [21]. The control method of the fresh air is worth noticing. Although the total volume of supply air is changed with the variation of indoor temperature setpoint, the volume of fresh air is controlled to fulfill the requirement of occupancy (30 m3/h per person). The schedule of person, lighting, and equipment load is shown in Fig. 4 . They are expressed in fractions of their respective peak values. 5.1.2 HVAC model There are two identical chillers, one for operation and another for reserve. The rated power consumption and cooling capacity of each chiller are 437 kW and 2461 kW respectively. The chiller model is presented in Eqs. 12–16 [29]. TRNSYS is a software whose package contains many developed models, including a building model and HVAC system component models. However, TRNSYS is written in FORTRAN language which is hard to implement advanced machine learning and optimization algorithms. In this study, Type 163 in TRNSYS is used which allows TRNSYS to communicate with the Python script. At each TRNSYS iteration, this type writes a file that includes the parameters set by the user at the start of the simulation and the inputs to the type. It then activates the Python script. The Python script reads the values from the file created by the type and performs the content written in the script. The script then writes a new file that contains the output values and returns control back to the TRNSYS type. Finally, the type reads the new file and passes the outputs on to the rest of the simulation [34]. In our trial study, it is found that the Type 163 can only work successfully with the connection to Python in version 3.6. That is the reason why an old version of python is used. 6 Result and discussion The result of XGBoost model validation is presented in Section 6.1. The computation cost is introduced in Section 6.2. In Sections 6.3 and 6.4, two case studies (based on the same day) are presented in which different punishment parameters are set to reflect different willingness for indoor temperature increase/sacrifice. In these case studies, the weather condition in coming hours is directly used for predicting power use and indoor temperature. It will be replaced by a weather forecast/estimator model when this work is expanded to a field test on real building plants. The use of actual rather than predicted weather data can slightly increase the prediction accuracy of indoor temperature and HVAC power use and then improve the control performance of the MPC controller compared to the real case. The impact of prediction accuracy on the control performance of the MPC controller will be studied in our future work. 6.1 Model validation Following the step introduced in Section 3.2, the hyperparameter turning was conducted and the results are introduced as follows. The max depth of a tree is 8, and the subsample ratio is 0.9. Alpha is 0 (default) and lambda is 0.4. The leaning rate is 0.05 and the number of trees is 200. In this study, a typical day is selected to validate the performance of the XGBoost models for predicting power use and indoor temperature. The predicted values and the actual values are compared and shown in Fig. 5 (power use) and Fig. 6 (indoor temperature). It should be noticed that in the model training and validation process, the indoor temperature setpoint is randomly set. Therefore, both the power use and indoor temperature have a large fluctuation. The entire dataset is divided into 5 splits for cross-validation. Four performance indices are used to evaluate the performance of the prediction model, including two scale-dependent metrics, mean absolute error (MAE), root means square error (RMSE), and two scale-independent metrics, R 2 and the coefficient of variation of the root mean squared error (CV-RMSE), which are presented in Table 1 and Table 2 . Artificial Neural Network (ANN) models after hyperparameter turning are developed for comparison. Each ANN model has two hidden layers. Each layer contains 250 neurons. The activation function is “relu” and the regularization parameter is 0.1. It can be observed in Table 1 and Table 2 that the performance of the XGBoost model is better than the ANN model. This performance improvement can have a non-negligible impact on the performance of MPC because the model is used iteratively to predict the behavior of the system in a long control horizon. 6.2 Computation cost The case studies are conducted on a TRNSYS-Python co-simulation test platform, which is on a desktop computer with Intel Core i7-10510U (1.80 GHz), 16 GB of memory, under Windows 10 64-bit operating system. A comparison is conducted as follows. In scenario one, the conventional rolling optimization is conducted in which all the individuals in the initial population of GA are randomly generated for each control step. In scenario two, the initial population of the genetic algorithm is designed using the information from the last step (detailed introduced in Section 4.3). The crossover rate and mutation rate in these two scenarios are the same. It is found that to achieve the same control performance (i.e., cost reduction), the case in scenario two needs less population size and iteration. In scenario one, the population size is 100 and the iteration is 20, while in scenario two, the population size is 50 and the iteration is 10. Because of the decrease in population size and the iteration, the case in scenario two needs less time (4 min) compared with that in scenario one (18 min). It should be noticed that although the simulation in TRNSYS and the interaction between TRNSYS and Python also account for computation resources, their total time consumption is less than 10 s. This means that dedicated generation of the initial population of GA can significantly save computation cost, as much as 78%. 6.3 Case 1: high punishment parameter in comfort cost In this case, a relatively high punishment parameter (i.e., 2500) in the comfort cost is selected. A baseline case study is also conducted when the indoor temperature is set constant at 25 °C. Fig. 7 shows the hourly electricity price and demand response reward price. Fig. 8 shows the indoor temperature setpoint and indoor temperature in Case 1. Fig. 9 shows the power use in Case 1 and the baseline case, respectively. The green area means the demand response period. It can be observed that the MPC controller can effectively increase the indoor temperature setpoint to decrease HVAC power use during the demand response period. In addition, it can also effectively decrease the indoor temperature setpoint for precooling. For example, the indoor temperature setpoint is decreased to the lower limit at 23.5 °C during the period from 12:00 to 14:00 which is just in the middle of two demand response periods. It should be noticed that because of the significant decrease in the indoor temperature setpoint, the peak power use of HVAC system increased compared with that in the baseline case. In Case 1, the largest part load ratio has reached 0.8. In real applications, the constraints of HVAC system should also be considered. It can also be observed from Fig. 8 that the indoor temperature setpoint doesn't fluctuate significantly, which can ensure the stable operation of the HVAC system. Fig. 10 shows the electricity cost ( C e ), financial reward ( C D R negative) in Case 1 and the electricity cost ( C e ) in the baseline case. It can be observed that the precooling behavior results in a slight increase in the electricity cost. By comparison, the electricity cost reduction during the demand response period is more significant because of a higher electricity price. Moreover, the financial reward ( C D R ) is also considerable. In Case 1, although the energy saving is only 1.86%, the total cost reduction obtained achieves as much as 27.3% while the weighted indoor temperature only increases by 0.14 K. Various types of cost and cost reduction in Case 1 and Case 2, and the comparison with the baseline case are presented in Table 3 . The values in this table can be referred to by commercial building managers, especially those in Guangdong Province regulated by the newly issued policy. To evaluate the thermal comfort of occupancies when the HVAC system is used for providing demand response. The humidity, Predicted Mean Vote (PMV) and Predicted Percentage of Dissatisfied (PPD) are also analyzed. Here, PMV is developed by Fanger and standardized in ASHRAE55 [35]. It is an index that predicts the mean value of the thermal sensation votes of a large group of people. Its value ranges from −3 to +3 corresponding to the feeling of cold, cool, slightly cool, neutral, slightly warm, warm, and hot. Once the PMV is calculated, the PPD can be determined. It reflects a prediction of the percentage of thermally dissatisfied occupants (i.e., too warm, or too cold). The clothing insulation is set as 0.5 clo (i.e., 0.08 m2 h/W). The airspeed is set to 0.1 m/s. The metabolic rate is set as 1.6 (i.e., 93.04 W/m2) [36]. The mean radiant temperature is set the same as the indoor temperature. Fig. 11 shows the variation of indoor temperature, humidity, PMV, and PDD in Case 1. It can be observed that the humidity decreases slightly during the demand response period. The main reason could be the indoor temperature increase. The range of PMV is between 0 and 1. The highest PMV is 0.71 which occurs at 17:00, and the corresponding PDD is 15.6%. 6.4 Case 2: low punishment parameter in comfort cost In this case, a relatively low punishment parameter (i.e., 1500) in the comfort cost is selected. Fig. 12 shows the indoor temperature setpoint and indoor temperature in Case 2. Fig. 13 shows the power use in Case 2 and the baseline case, respectively. It can be observed that the MPC controller can also effectively increase the indoor temperature setpoint during demand response period and decrease the indoor temperature setpoint before the demand response period for precooling. However, because of the low punishment parameter set in the comfort cost, the minimum indoor temperature setpoint is 24.5 °C, even during the period from 12:00 to 14:00 which is between two demand response periods. According to the calculation, the weighted indoor temperature increases by 0.62 K, and the total cost reduction achieved is 33.6% (relative information is shown in Fig. 14 ). The energy saving is 9.02%. Same as that in Case 1, the relative humidity decreases slightly during the first demand response period (from 10:00 to 12:00). However, during the second demand response period (from 14:00 to 17:00), the humidity doesn't change obviously as the indoor temperature almost reach its up limit (26.5 °C). The highest PMV obtained in Case 2 is 0.72 which occurs at 12:00, and the corresponding PDD is 15.9% (see Fig. 15). To further verify the control performance, a simulation of a week is conducted. The main results are shown in Fig. 16 . It is found that the average weighted indoor temperature increase is 0.48 K and the average total cost reduction is 34.3%, which further demonstrates the robustness of the proposed control method. 7 Conclusion In this study, an XGBoost-based predictive control strategy is proposed for HVAC systems in providing day-ahead demand response. XGBoost models are developed to predict the variation of power use and indoor temperature. Several innovations are implemented to improve the control performance for real applications, including dedicated generation of the initial population of genetic algorithm in the process of rolling optimization, the use of a step-decreasing control horizon, and the separation of the sampling period and control action period. The strategy is validated on a TRNSYS-Python co-simulation test platform which is developed based on a real commercial building in Shenzhen, China where a novel detailed day-ahead demand response policy was issued in April of 2022. The main conclusions are as follows. • The proposed XGBoost-based predictive control strategy can effectively control the indoor temperature to provide demand response with an acceptable indoor temperature increase. In this study, compared with the traditional operation, the proposed control strategy can reduce the total cost by as much as 27.30% and 33.6% while the weighted indoor temperature only increases by 0.14 K and 0.62 K, respectively. • The XGBoost model has a better performance than the ANN model for predicting indoor temperature and HVAC power use in a short period under the condition when the indoor temperature setpoint is changed. In this study, only using one-week historical data, the CV-RMSEs of XGBoost models in predicting HVAC power use and indoor temperature in the coming 10 min are 4.52% and 0.40%, respectively. • The dedicated generation of the initial population of GA using the information from the last control step in the process of rolling optimization can significantly decrease the computation cost while maintaining the control performance of MPC. In this study, the running time of the case decreases from 18 min to 4 min, which means as much as 78% computation cost reduction is achieved. • The humidity decreases slightly when the HVAC system is used to provide the demand response. The main reason could be the indoor temperature increase. The PMV and PDD are acceptable during demand response period. In this study, the highest value of PMV and PDD are 0.71 and 15.6% in Case 1, and 0.72 and 15.9% in Case 2. coredata.dc:description: Heating, ventilation and air-conditioning systems (HVAC), at demand side, are regarded as promising candidates to provide demand response to smart power grids by adjusting indoor temperature setpoint. However, the optimal control of indoor temperature setpoint with the constraint of indoor environment is a key issue. In this study, an XGBoost-based predictive control strategy is proposed for HVAC systems in providing day-ahead demand response. XGBoost (Extreme Gradient Boosting) models are developed to predict the variation of power use and indoor temperature. Several innovations are implemented to improve the performance of the control strategy, including dedicated generation of the initial population of genetic algorithm (GA) in rolling optimization, the use of a step-decreasing control horizon, and the separation of the sampling period and control action period. The strategy is validated on a TRNSYS-Python co-simulation test platform. Results show that the developed XGBoost models can achieve a high prediction performance of power use (CV-RMSE of 4.52%) and indoor temperature (CV-RMSE of 0.40%) in the coming 10 min with only using one-week historical data. The computation cost is reduced by 78% due to the dedicated generation of GA initial population while the control performance is not affected. Compared with the traditional operation, the proposed control strategy can reduce the total cost by as much as 27.30% and 33.6% while the weighted indoor temperature only increases by 0.14 K and 0.62 K, respectively. In test cases, the highest Predicted Mean Vote (PMV) is 0.72 and the corresponding Predicted Percentage of Dissatisfied (PPD) is 15.9%.
coredata.dc:title: An XGBoost-Based predictive control strategy for HVAC systems in providing day-ahead demand response
